title: German submarine U-777
text:
German submarine "U-777" was a <a href="Nazi%20Germany">German</a> <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 25 March 1944, and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 9 May, by its sole commander, <a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a> Günter Ruperti.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-777" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Garbe%2C%20Lahmeyer%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Garbe, Lahmeyer & Co.</a> RP 137/c <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-777" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, (220 rounds), one <a href="3.7%20cm%20Flak%2018/36/37/43">Flak M42</a> and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft guns. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
It underwent training with the <a href="31st%20U-boat%20Flotilla">31st U-boat Flotilla</a>, but did not participate in any patrols during its five-month career of active service. It was destroyed at 20:02 hours on the night of 15/16 October 1944, during a British air raid on <a href="Wilhelmshaven">Wilhelmshaven</a>, Germany, at position . One crewman was killed.
